Title: Time to pay up? Reparations and global development challenges

This project, REPAIR, addresses the timely and pressing issue of reparations in global development contexts. As the world grapples with infectious disease outbreaks, climate change, minority rights violations, and toxic environments, calls for reparations are increasingly prominent. Yet, there is a lack of comparative research on reparations in development settings. REPAIR fills this gap by studying reparations payments in these four areas, examining how they are established, implemented, and received.

The project's objectives are threefold. First, it will compare reparations payments across different global development challenges. Second, it will analyze what these payments reveal about reparations from economic, moral, and political perspectives. Third, it will identify the type of wealth transfer reparations constitute and what this tells us about the 'reparative aspects' of economic life.

REPAIR's innovative approach lies in its comparative scope, novel theory, and methods from economic anthropology. By broadening the comparative frame of reparations study, this project will provide new insights into the role of reparations in addressing global development challenges. The project's focus on reparations as a form of wealth transfer and its examination of the 'reparative aspects' of economic activity will also contribute to a deeper understanding of the economic, moral, and political implications of reparations. Ultimately, REPAIR aims to inform policy and practice on reparations, promoting more effective and equitable responses to global development challenges.

This project, REPAIR, undertakes the first comprehensive comparative social-science study of reparations in the context of global development. It examines four critical areas where reparations are increasingly being demanded: infectious disease outbreaks, climate change, minority rights violations, and toxic environments. Through a mixed-methods approach, REPAIR aims to achieve three primary objectives. First, it will compare how reparations payments are established, implemented, and received in addressing global development challenges. Second, it will explore what these payments reveal about reparations from economic, moral, and political perspectives. Third, it will identify the type of wealth transfer reparations constitute and what this tells us about the 'reparative aspects' of economic life. By broadening the comparative frame of reparations study and employing novel theory and methods from economic anthropology, REPAIR will provide fresh insights into the role of reparations in global development and the nature of economic activity. The project's findings will have significant implications for policymakers, practitioners, and scholars working to address global development challenges and promote more equitable and sustainable economic systems.
